questions.question: In a coherent Frequency Shift Keying (FSK) system, what is the primary challenge in achieving coherent detection?

answers.a: Maintaining phase synchronization between transmitter and receiver
answers.b: Ensuring the amplitude of the carrier signals remain constant
answers.d: Reducing the noise floor of the system

explanations.a: Coherent detection requires maintaining phase synchronization to correctly demodulate the signal.
explanations.b: Amplitude consistency is less critical in FSK as it relies on frequency changes.
explanations.c: Frequency deviation is not the primary challenge in coherent detection.
explanations.d: While important, reducing the noise floor is not specific to coherent detection.

questions.question: Which of the following is a major disadvantage of Amplitude Shift Keying (ASK)?

explanations.a: ASK is highly susceptible to noise because it relies on amplitude changes.
explanations.b: ASK is generally simpler to implement than other modulation types.
explanations.c: ASK does not inherently require high bandwidth compared to other modulations.

questions.question: Which modulation scheme is typically more bandwidth-efficient?

explanations.a: ASK is not as bandwidth-efficient due to its simple encoding.
explanations.b: FSK requires more bandwidth due to frequency changes.
explanations.c: PSK is more bandwidth-efficient because it encodes information in phase shifts.
explanations.d: PAM is not inherently more bandwidth-efficient than PSK.

questions.question: In Phase Shift Keying (PSK), what is the impact of increasing the number of phase states?

explanations.a: Increasing the number of phase states makes the system more sensitive to noise.
explanations.b: More phase states generally require similar or increased bandwidth.
explanations.c: More phase states allow higher data rates as more bits can be encoded per symbol.
explanations.d: The receiver design becomes more complex with more phase states.

questions.question: Which of the following is a key advantage of using Non-Coherent FSK over Coherent FSK?

explanations.a: Non-Coherent FSK has a simpler receiver design because it does not require phase synchronization.
explanations.b: Coherent FSK can achieve higher data rates due to phase detection.
explanations.c: Non-Coherent FSK does not inherently use less power.
explanations.d: Non-Coherent FSK does not generally perform better in noise compared to Coherent FSK.

questions.question: Why is Phase Shift Keying (PSK) considered more power efficient than Frequency Shift Keying (FSK)?

answers.a: PSK can maintain performance at lower signal-to-noise ratios.
answers.d: PSK does not require frequency modulation.

explanations.a: PSK is more power efficient because it can achieve good performance at lower signal-to-noise ratios.
explanations.b: PSK typically requires similar bandwidth compared to FSK.
explanations.c: PSK is often more complex due to synchronization requirements.
explanations.d: PSK relies on phase modulation rather than frequency modulation.

questions.question: Which characteristic of FSK modulation makes it advantageous for certain applications?

answers.c: Its ability to encode more data per symbol

explanations.a: FSK is not directly related to phase jitter.
explanations.b: FSK is robust in noisy environments because the frequency changes are distinct.
explanations.c: FSK does not inherently encode more data per symbol than other methods.
explanations.d: FSK typically requires more bandwidth due to the frequency changes.

questions.question: What is the primary disadvantage of using higher-order PSK modulation schemes?

explanations.a: Higher-order PSK does not necessarily increase bandwidth usage.
explanations.b: Higher-order PSK does not inherently require more power.
explanations.c: Increased sensitivity to noise due to smaller phase differences between symbols.
explanations.d: PSK is not typically associated with amplitude variations.

questions.question: Which modulation scheme is typically used in radio broadcasting?

explanations.a: ASK is not typically used in radio broadcasting.
explanations.b: FM is commonly used in radio broadcasting due to its robustness to noise.
explanations.c: PSK is used in digital communication, not typically in radio broadcasting.
explanations.d: FSK is used in digital communication, not typically in radio broadcasting.

questions.question: In a PSK system, what can be used to improve error performance?

answers.d: Increasing the power of the transmitted signal

explanations.a: Increasing the carrier frequency does not directly improve error performance.
explanations.b: Error correction coding helps to detect and correct errors, improving performance.
explanations.c: Reducing modulation order decreases data rate but improves error performance.
explanations.d: Increasing power can improve signal-to-noise ratio, enhancing performance.
